questions.answer_description:
When you view dashboards in portrait mode on a phone, you notice the dashboard tiles are laid out one after another, all the same size. In the Power BI service, you can create a customized view of a dashboard, specifically for portrait mode on phones.
Step 1: Open the Dashboard.
Step 2: Change the dashboard view to Phone view
Step 3: Pin items from the reports to the dashboard.
Step 4: Rearrange, resize, or remote items from the Phone view.
Create a phone view of a dashboard
1. In the Power BI service, open a dashboard (Step 1)
2. Select the arrow next to Web view in the upper-right corner > select Phone view. (Step 2)

The phone dashboard edit view opens. Here you can unpin, resize, and rearrange tiles to fit the phone view. The web version of the dashboard doesn't change.
3. Select a tile to drag, resize, or unpin it. You notice the other tiles move out of the way as you drag a tile.
The unpinned tiles go in the Unpinned tiles pane, where they stay unless you add them back.
4. If you change your mind, select Reset tiles to put them back in the size and order they were before.
5. When you're satisfied with the phone dashboard layout, select the arrow next to Phone view in the upper-right corner > select Web view.
Power BI saves the phone layout automatically.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/create-reports/service-create-dashboard-mobile-phone-view

Here's the reasoning, 
1. Open the dashboard: This is the first step to access and modify the dashboard.
2. Pin items from the reports to the dashboard: Select the visuals you want to include from the reports and pin them to the dashboard.
3. Change the dashboard view to Phone view: This activates the phone view mode specifically designed for mobile phone portrait orientation.
4. Rearrange, resize, or remove items from the phone view: In this view, you can customize the layout for mobile users by rearranging the visuals, resizing them to fit the screen, or removing any that might not be essential for the mobile view.

Importance
- You can't rearrange or resize items unless they're already pinned to the dashboard.
- Switching to phone view first wouldn't allow you to pin items because the phone view focuses on customizing existing dashboard elements.

questions.question_text:
You build a report to help the sales team understand its performance and the drivers of sales.
The team needs to have a single visualization to identify which factors affect success.
Which type of visualization should you use?

HOTSPOT -
You have a dataset named Pens that contains the following columns:
✑ Unit Price
✑ Quantity Ordered
You need to create a visualization that shows the relationship between Unit Price and Quantity Ordered. The solution must highlight orders that have a similar unit price and ordered quantity.
Which type of visualization and which feature should you use? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//
questions.answer_description:
Box 1: A scatter plot...
A scatter chart always has two value axes to show: one set of numerical data along a horizontal axis and another set of numerical values along a vertical axis. The chart displays points at the intersection of an x and y numerical value, combining these values into single data points. Power BI may distribute these data points evenly or unevenly across the horizontal axis. It depends on the data the chart represents.
Box 2: Automatically find clusters
Scatter charts are a great choice to show patterns in large sets of data, for example by showing linear or non-linear trends, clusters, and outliers.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/power-bi/visuals/power-bi-visualization-scatter
